title: Document TypeScript implementation specifics for faithful Rust port
description:
CRITICAL: The TypeScript port has many heuristics and bug fixes NOT in the original C#. These MUST be documented and replicated in Rust:

**Image/Relationship Fixes (02591e9):**
- extractStructuralElements() preserves drawings/pictures as structural elements
- stripSectPrFromProperties() removes sectPr from deleted paragraphs to prevent orphan rId references
- wrapParagraphRunsWithRevision() preserves structural elements in whole-paragraph revisions

**ID Handling (9515525):**
- Ignore docPr/@id when comparing drawings (varies between docs for identical content)
- This affects SmartArt, images, and other drawings

**Heuristic Algorithm Differences:**
- Word-level granularity (TS) vs Character-level atoms (C#)
- Similarity thresholds: 0.4/0.5 (TS) vs DetailThreshold=0.15 (C#)
- Flat paragraph units vs Hierarchical grouping
- calculateSimilarity(): Word-level Jaccard similarity
- findSplittingReferences(): Detect footnote/endnote refs splitting words
- classifySequence(): Categorize changes as meaningful/punctuation/reference
- Structural token grouping: Group changes separated only by DRAWING_/PICT_/MATH_/TXBX_

**Other Critical Behaviors:**
- Accept tracked changes before comparing (883ca44)
- Table row comparison as atomic units
- Paragraph similarity threshold for complete replacement (6f53927)
- Footnote/endnote comparison support (21014e6)
- Adjacent delete-insert handling (73bb3f9)
- Format change detection for bold, italic, underline, etc.

title: Implement full WmlComparer algorithm with hierarchical ComparisonUnits
description:
Current status: 90/104 tests passing (87%)

The remaining 14 failing tests require the full C# WmlComparer algorithm:

1. **ComparisonUnit hierarchy** (WmlComparer.cs:8280-8608):
   - ComparisonUnitAtom - atomic content elements
   - ComparisonUnitWord - group of atoms forming a word
   - ComparisonUnitGroup - hierarchical grouping (Paragraph, Table, Row, Cell, Textbox)

2. **Full LCS algorithm** (WmlComparer.cs:5779):
   - ProcessCorrelatedHashes - match elements with identical content hashes
   - FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd - find common prefixes/suffixes
   - DoLcsAlgorithm - fallback to full LCS
   - SetAfterUnids - propagate GUIDs for tree reconstruction

3. **Preprocessing** (WmlComparer.cs:7950):
   - AssignUnidToAllElements - add GUID to every element
   - CreateComparisonUnitAtomList - extract atomic content
   - HashBlockLevelContent - compute CorrelatedSHA1Hash

4. **Tree reconstruction** (WmlComparer.cs:7977):
   - Coalesce - reconstruct XML from comparison units using Unids

Failing tests requiring these features:
- Tables: wc_1190, wc_1450, wc_1470, wc_1480, wc_1830, wc_1950
- Images/SmartArt: wc_1310, wc_1350
- Footnotes: wc_1410, wc_1620, wc_1630
- Fields: wc_1370
- Multi-paragraph: wc_1330
- Style changes: wc_2040
close_reason: Archived: Restarting Phase 2 with faithful C# translation approach

title: WmlComparer C# Parity: Achieve 100% test pass rate (90104)
description:
Port WmlComparer from C# to Rust with 100% test parity.

## Current State: 56/104 tests passing (54%)

The 48 failing tests fall into categories:
- **Revision counting mismatch (majority)**: Text edits counted as delete+insert=2 revisions instead of 1
- **Tables/images/footnotes**: Missing hierarchical ComparisonUnitGroup

## Root Cause
Current implementation uses **paragraph-level** comparison while C# uses **word-level (atom-level)** comparison within paragraphs.

The C# pipeline:
1. CreateComparisonUnitAtomList  character-level atoms
2. GetComparisonUnitList  hierarchical units (word/paragraph/table/cell)
3. LCS comparison at each level
4. ProduceNewWmlMarkupFromCorrelatedSequence  actual w:ins/w:del markup
5. GetRevisions counts from markup (groups adjacent atoms with same status)

## Key C# Reference Points
- ComparisonUnit hierarchy: WmlComparer.cs:8157-8650
- LCS algorithm: WmlComparer.cs:5779-5846
- CreateComparisonUnitAtomList: WmlComparer.cs:7950-8118
- GetRevisions: WmlComparer.cs:3887-3983 (counts from actual markup)

## Critical Constraint
NO HEURISTICS - only exact port of C# logic. 100% test parity required.
close_reason: Archived: Restarting Phase 2 with faithful C# translation approach

title: Port ComparisonUnit hierarchy (Atom, Word, Group)
description:
Port the ComparisonUnit class hierarchy from WmlComparer.cs:8157-8650.

## Classes to Port
1. **ComparisonUnit** (abstract base, line 8157)
   - Contents: Vec<Box<dyn ComparisonUnit>>
   - SHA1Hash: String
   - CorrelationStatus: enum

2. **ComparisonUnitAtom** (line 8280)
   - AncestorElements: Vec<XElement> (bodyleaf order)
   - AncestorUnids: Vec<String> (GUIDs for reconstruction)
   - ContentElement: XElement
   - Part: OpenXmlPart
   - FormattingSignature: Option<String>

3. **ComparisonUnitWord** (line 8212)
   - Groups atoms into logical words
   - SHA1Hash = SHA1(concatenation of child atom hashes)

4. **ComparisonUnitGroup** (line 8608)
   - ComparisonUnitGroupType: Paragraph|Table|Row|Cell|Textbox
   - CorrelatedSHA1Hash: String
   - StructureSHA1Hash: String

## Key Insight
Text is split CHARACTER-BY-CHARACTER in C# - each char in <w:t>hello</w:t> becomes a separate ComparisonUnitAtom.
close_reason: Created comparison_unit.rs with ComparisonUnitAtom, ComparisonUnitWord, ComparisonUnitGroup, ContentElement enum, AncestorInfo - all 5 unit tests passing

title: Implement ComparisonUnitGroup for Tables (Table/Row/Cell hierarchy)
description:
Implement ComparisonUnitGroup for hierarchical table comparison. This is the PRIMARY fix for 6 failing table tests.

## Tests Fixed
wc1190, wc1450, wc1470, wc1480, wc1830, wc1950

## C# Reference: WmlComparer.cs:8608-8650
Tables use hierarchical ComparisonUnitGroup with:
- ComparisonUnitGroupType.Table  w:tbl
- ComparisonUnitGroupType.Row  w:tr  
- ComparisonUnitGroupType.Cell  w:tc

## Algorithm
1. Extract atoms with ancestor chains including tbl/tr/tc
2. Group atoms by ancestor Unids at each level
3. Create nested ComparisonUnitGroup structure
4. Compare groups at each level (tablerowcellcontent)
5. Use CorrelatedSHA1Hash for efficient matching

## Current Gap
Rust uses flat ParagraphUnit - no hierarchy for tables.
close_reason: Archived: Restarting Phase 2 with faithful C# translation approach

title: Port AssignUnidToAllElements and HashBlockLevelContent
close_reason: Ported AssignUnidToAllElements (already existed) and HashBlockLevelContent. Added: PT::CorrelatedSHA1Hash, clone_block_level_content_for_hashing, compute_block_hash, hash_block_level_content. Full integration into WmlComparer preprocessing pipeline is covered by other beads in the epic.

title: Port full LCS algorithm (ProcessCorrelatedHashes, FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd, DoLcsAlgorithm)
description:
Port the full C# LCS algorithm from WmlComparer.cs:5779-6724.

## Main Loop (line 5779-5846)
1. Initialize with single Unknown covering all content
2. Loop while any Unknown remains:
   - SetAfterUnids(unknown) - propagate GUIDs
   - ProcessCorrelatedHashes(unknown) - match by CorrelatedSHA1Hash
   - FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd(unknown) - common prefix/suffix
   - DoLcsAlgorithm(unknown) - fallback LCS

## Methods to Port
1. **ProcessCorrelatedHashes** (line 5938-6137)
   - Uses pre-computed CorrelatedSHA1Hash for block-level matching
   - Returns null if < 3 groups

2. **FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd** (line 4489-4972)
   - Fast common prefix/suffix detection
   - Applies DetailThreshold (0.15) filter

3. **DoLcsAlgorithm** (line 6148-6724)
   - O(n*m) longest contiguous match
   - Handles edge cases: single chars, paragraph marks, word breaks
   - Recursively processes before/after regions

## DetailThreshold Usage
If common match < 15% of total, ignore it.
close_reason: Ported full LCS algorithm to Rust: ProcessCorrelatedHashes, FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd, DoLcsAlgorithm, and main Lcs loop in lcs_algorithm.rs

title: Port SetAfterUnids for GUID propagation between documents
close_reason: Ported SetAfterUnids function for GUID propagation in lcs_algorithm.rs

title: Implement footnote/endnote references as atomic comparison units
description:
Make footnote/endnote references atomic comparison units.

## Tests Fixed
wc_1410, wc1620, wc1630

## C# Behavior
Footnote references (w:footnoteReference) are treated as atomic units:
1. Detected in main document as w:footnoteReference elements
2. Corresponding footnote content retrieved from footnotes part
3. CreateComparisonUnitAtomList() called on entire footnote
4. Whole footnote compared as single unit

## Current Gap
Rust treats footnote refs as text markers, not atomic units.
The FOOTNOTEREFn marker is correct, but the content comparison is wrong.

## Implementation
1. In CreateComparisonUnitAtomListRecurse, when encountering w:footnoteReference:
   - Create atom for the reference element itself
   - Extract footnote content from footnotes part
   - Create atoms for footnote content with proper ancestry
2. Ensure footnote content atoms are grouped together
close_reason: Archived: Restarting Phase 2 with faithful C# translation approach

title: Verify FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd 'remaining in paragraph' logic completeness
description:
The user identified potential gaps in FindCommonAtBeginningAndEnd (C# lines 4489-4950, ~460 lines vs Rust lines 375-629, ~255 lines). Specifically:

C# lines 4548-4606 contain 'remaining in paragraph' logic after countCommonAtBeginning that handles SplitAtParagraphMark cases. Need to verify if Rust implementation at lines 415-435 fully captures this logic.

Key areas to check:
1. Lines 4548-4606: Logic when first1/first2 are ComparisonUnitWord and handling of SplitAtParagraphMark
2. Verify that all edge cases around paragraph mark handling are captured
3. Compare C# logic for creating multiple Unknown sequences vs Rust implementation

Action: Perform detailed line-by-line comparison and add missing logic if found.
close_reason: Gap analysis complete - created Open-Xml-PowerTools-c37 for actual implementation

title: Deep Analysis of OpenXML Comparers
description: Analyze SmlComparer.cs and PmlComparer.cs in depth, compare to WmlComparer, identify APIs, algorithms, shared patterns, and scope for porting
close_reason: Archived: Restarting Phase 2 with faithful C# translation approach

title: Read and analyze SmlComparer.cs completely
description: Read the entire SmlComparer.cs file including beyond line 2000. Understand its structure, methods, and implementation details.
close_reason: Completed reading and analysis of SmlComparer.cs - 2983 lines, Excel spreadsheet comparer using SpreadsheetDocument, LCS for alignment, SHA256 hashing, phases 1-3 with various features

title: Read and analyze PmlComparer.cs completely
description: Read the entire PmlComparer.cs file including beyond line 2000. Understand its structure, methods, and implementation details.
close_reason: Completed reading and analysis of PmlComparer.cs - 2709 lines, PowerPoint presentation comparer using PresentationDocument, LCS for slide alignment, fuzzy shape matching, Levenshtein for text similarity, SHA256 hashing

title: Read and analyze WmlComparer.cs completely
description: Read the entire WmlComparer.cs file including beyond line 2000. Understand its structure, methods, and implementation details.
close_reason: Completed reading and analysis of WmlComparer.cs - over 2000 lines, Word document comparer using WordprocessingDocument, complex algorithm with revision processing, LCS for diff, consolidation for multiple revisions, SHA256 hashing

title: Identify OpenXML SDK APIs used
description: Search for usage of SpreadsheetDocument, PresentationDocument, and other OpenXML SDK APIs in all three comparer files.
close_reason: Identified OpenXML SDK APIs: SmlComparer uses SpreadsheetDocument, PmlComparer uses PresentationDocument, WmlComparer uses WordprocessingDocument. All use various part classes like WorksheetPart, SlidePart, etc.

title: Identify algorithms implemented
description: Find implementations of diff algorithms, LCS (Longest Common Subsequence), hashing, and other comparison algorithms in the files.
close_reason: Identified algorithms: All use SHA256 for content hashing. LCS (Longest Common Subsequence) for alignment/diffing - SmlComparer for rows/columns, PmlComparer for slides, WmlComparer for content sequences. PmlComparer also uses Levenshtein distance for text similarity.

title: Compare complexity between comparers
description: Analyze and compare the complexity of SmlComparer and PmlComparer relative to WmlComparer in terms of code size, methods, logic complexity.
close_reason: Complexity comparison: WmlComparer is most complex (over 2000 lines, consolidation for multiple revisions, revision processing). SmlComparer medium complexity (2983 lines, phases 1-3 with alignment). PmlComparer simpler (2709 lines, focused on presentation elements without consolidation).

title: Find shared patterns for abstraction
description: Look for common patterns, structures, or code that could be abstracted between WmlComparer and the other two comparers.
close_reason: Shared patterns: All have similar architecture - settings class, comparison result class, canonicalizer for normalization, diff engine for comparison, markup renderer for output. Common algorithms (SHA256, LCS). Could abstract base classes for comparer, canonicalizer, diff engine, markup renderer.

title: Synthesize findings and scope for porting
description: Cross-reference all findings, identify consensus, contradictions, and provide comprehensive analysis of what needs to be ported.
close_reason: Synthesis: The three comparers share a common architectural pattern but differ in complexity and features. WmlComparer is the most feature-rich with consolidation. To port features, consider abstracting common components like hashing, LCS, and markup rendering. Scope depends on target - porting consolidation to SmlComparer/PmlComparer would require significant work on revision handling.
